unnormalised: **Manufacturing & Supply Chain: Quality Control Crucial for 'Make in India' Success**
normalised: Manufacturing and Supply Chain: Quality Control Crucial for 'Make in India' Success

unnormalised: Ensuring robust quality control is paramount to the success of the 'Make in India' initiative and the overall competitiveness of Indian manufacturing. Experts at IIT-Bombay highlighted this crucial need during a workshop held on 26/01/2024.
normalised: Ensuring robust quality control is paramount to the success of the 'Make in India' initiative and the overall competitiveness of Indian manufacturing. Experts at I I T-Bombay highlighted this crucial need during a workshop held on twenty sixth january two thousand and twenty four.

unnormalised: Poor quality can lead to significant financial losses for businesses, impacting brand reputation and consumer trust. Think of a batch of substandard Diwali diyas flooding the market – a small defect multiplied across thousands of units results in a big problem.
normalised: Poor quality can lead to significant financial losses for businesses, impacting brand reputation and consumer trust. Think of a batch of substandard Diwali diyas flooding the market – a small defect multiplied across thousands of units results in a big problem.

unnormalised: Effective quality control requires a multi-pronged approach, encompassing rigorous testing at every stage of the supply chain, from raw material procurement to final product dispatch. Implementing Statistical Process Control (SPC) and Six Sigma methodologies, tailored to the Indian context, can help minimize defects. Regular audits, planned around events like Holi on 25/03, are also essential. Companies can explore certifications like ISO 9001 to demonstrate their commitment. Remember, the success of manufacturing hubs like Tirupur hinges on consistent quality. An internal meeting is scheduled for 14:00 hrs on 10/02/2024 to review current QC protocols.
